Timothy Tanå¯¹æ‰€æœ‰äººè¯´ï¼š (9:39 ä¸Šåˆ)
â€©Could you explain again why the server only needs to wait for one completion, instead of waiting for the same amount as tx_depth?â€©
Dai Zhangå¯¹æ‰€æœ‰äººè¯´ï¼š (9:45 ä¸Šåˆ)
â€©Is the NIC truly duplex, that is, can it write to RR receive buffer and read from SR send buffer at the same time, or it has to do them without overlap.â€©
Timothy Tanå¯¹æ‰€æœ‰äººè¯´ï¼š (9:47 ä¸Šåˆ)
â€©Okok thanks!â€©
é—«åŠ›æ•å¯¹æ‰€æœ‰äººè¯´ï¼š (9:47 ä¸Šåˆ)
â€©thankxâ€©
Timothy Tanå¯¹æ‰€æœ‰äººè¯´ï¼š (9:56 ä¸Šåˆ)
â€©For the last point, is it correct to say that the NIC can overcome PCI latency by reading more data from the memory even before previous packets have started sending in the network?â€©
Gilå¯¹æ‰€æœ‰äººè¯´ï¼š (9:58 ä¸Šåˆ)
â€©Yes, it is.â€©
Dai Zhangå¯¹æ‰€æœ‰äººè¯´ï¼š (10:00 ä¸Šåˆ)
â€©If read & write can be done at the same time, even though we donâ€™t care about the actual data, will it cause some issues if we try to read/write the same part of memory from NIC, for example, conflicts in pcie bus or some software issues (sorry for aggressive guesses, I have no idea about the pcie system). In ping-pong example, the SR/RR bufs are at the same place.â€©
Dai Zhangå¯¹æ‰€æœ‰äººè¯´ï¼š (10:08 ä¸Šåˆ)
â€©Thank you!â€©
Timothy Tanå¯¹æ‰€æœ‰äººè¯´ï¼š (10:25 ä¸Šåˆ)
â€©Not yet :(â€©
Xinhao Kongå¯¹æ‰€æœ‰äººè¯´ï¼š (10:25 ä¸Šåˆ)
â€©run the examples/ucp_client_server successfullyâ€©
Lih Weiå¯¹æ‰€æœ‰äººè¯´ï¼š (10:25 ä¸Šåˆ)
â€©Yes, but incompleteâ€©
Yuwei Xuå¯¹æ‰€æœ‰äººè¯´ï¼š (10:25 ä¸Šåˆ)
â€©Yesâ€©
Dai Zhangå¯¹æ‰€æœ‰äººè¯´ï¼š (10:25 ä¸Šåˆ)
â€©yesâ€©
zmcå¯¹æ‰€æœ‰äººè¯´ï¼š (10:25 ä¸Šåˆ)
â€©Yes, but incomplete

Lih Weiå¯¹æ‰€æœ‰äººè¯´ï¼š (10:49 ä¸Šåˆ)
â€©If we are not using the worker function on a separate thread, is there any guarantees in terms of how long the worker function will take to return?

Also, are there any dangers of lost data if we call the worker too infrequently? It seems that as long as we use separate buffers, regardless if we use eager or rendezvous, it should be safe?â€©For the first part, coming from a perspective of cooperative multi-processing, if I have many requests in-flight, is there danger of starving my computations?â€©Thank youâ€©

Qiang Wangå¯¹æ‰€æœ‰äººè¯´ï¼š (11:18 ä¸Šåˆ)
â€©Hi, professor. It seems that the code tries to check the status in a loop while the request is uncompleted. Is it inefficient?â€©Ok. I see.

Dai Zhangå¯¹æ‰€æœ‰äººè¯´ï¼š (11:39 ä¸Šåˆ)
â€©Avoid disorderâ€©
Lih Weiå¯¹æ‰€æœ‰äººè¯´ï¼š (11:39 ä¸Šåˆ)
â€©Is it some form of flow control?â€©I seeâ€©
Lih Weiå¯¹æ‰€æœ‰äººè¯´ï¼š (11:45 ä¸Šåˆ)
â€©In UCX, is there any unreliable/UDP-like paradigm? Or is there a way to broadcast data (point-to-multipoint)?â€©Thank youâ€©
Lih Weiå¯¹æ‰€æœ‰äººè¯´ï¼š (12:33 ä¸‹åˆ)
â€©6 seconds?â€©*10â€©Apologies, I might have missed it, why canâ€™t all the processes receive simultaneously? Iâ€™m assuming each process is on a different linkâ€©
Lih Weiå¯¹æ‰€æœ‰äººè¯´ï¼š (12:39 ä¸‹åˆ)
â€©I think I get it, thank youâ€©
Qiang Wangå¯¹æ‰€æœ‰äººè¯´ï¼š (12:48 ä¸‹åˆ)
â€©Hi. Professor. I am still confused that why the shift algorithm is O(n) for MPI_Alltoall. Is it because that all the received processes can deal with data in parallel. Could you explain more, please?

Gilå¯¹æ‰€æœ‰äººè¯´ï¼š (1:09 ä¸‹åˆ)
â€©If all processes will send data to one process at the same time, it takes { (N * DataSize) / BW ) time for this process to receive this data.â€©Before the shift algorithm, in each [iâ€©Before the shift algorithm, in each [I] iteration we have all the processes sending to the iâ€™th process.â€©
Gilå¯¹æ‰€æœ‰äººè¯´ï¼š (1:11 ä¸‹åˆ)
â€©So each iteration is in the order of N (number of processes). Now we have N such iterations (for loop) so we end up with o(N^2)â€©So the problem is that we send from all processes to one process at the same time.â€©
Gilå¯¹æ‰€æœ‰äººè¯´ï¼š (1:13 ä¸‹åˆ)
â€©When we say that a receiving process can receive data from multiple processes in parallel, it is still limited in the link BWâ€©
Qiang Wangå¯¹æ‰€æœ‰äººè¯´ï¼š (1:18 ä¸‹åˆ)
â€©I see. So it is O(N^2) for â€œall the processes sending to the iâ€™th process in each [i] iteration.â€. What about the shift? Does it mean that we have each process sending data to different processes in each iteration?â€©
Gilå¯¹æ‰€æœ‰äººè¯´ï¼š (1:36 ä¸‹åˆ)
â€©Yes, this is the idea behind the shift schemeâ€©At each iteration, each process is sending data to a different processâ€©
Gilå¯¹æ‰€æœ‰äººè¯´ï¼š (1:37 ä¸‹åˆ)
â€©At first iteration,
process 1 sends to process 2
process 2 sends to process 3
â€¦
Process N sends to process 1â€©
Qiang Wangå¯¹æ‰€æœ‰äººè¯´ï¼š (1:39 ä¸‹åˆ)
â€©I see. It is somehow like multi-processing. However both two methods can still be limited in the link BW. Thank you very much!

So we can not install it.â€©Ok, thank youâ€©Dai Zhangå¯¹æ‰€æœ‰äººè¯´ï¼š (4:07 ä¸‹åˆ)â€©An question about the TAG SEND interface.â€©the tag_send interface takes in arguments like. "request = ucp_tag_send_nb(ep, bm_ctx.buf, 1, ucp_dt_make_contig(1), TAG, send_cb);"â€©Dai Zhangå¯¹æ‰€æœ‰äººè¯´ï¼š (4:07 ä¸‹åˆ)â€©where a **count**, and a **datatype**, are used to describe the buffer size. How's the underlying differences about these two args, or it is just a semantic explanation about the memory layout, and the underlying just sends "count x datatype" size of data block no matter how these two args are specified.â€©Dai Zhangå¯¹æ‰€æœ‰äººè¯´ï¼š (4:09 ä¸‹åˆ)â€©Yes, ucxâ€©Nothing in doc about the underlying mechanismsâ€©Cheng Liå¯¹æ‰€æœ‰äººè¯´ï¼š (4:14 ä¸‹åˆ)â€©Thanks all. Enjoy the rest of your journey!â€©Dai Zhangå¯¹æ‰€æœ‰äººè¯´ï¼š (4:14 ä¸‹åˆ)â€©Another question, is there any way to separate polling completion with another worker from the one sending requests in UCX. It seems that UCX interface has to progress the same worker to trigger callbacks on sent request. Is that means we always need to schedule the cpu time between sending requests and processing completions at the same core in UCX.Lih Weiå¯¹æ‰€æœ‰äººè¯´ï¼š (4:15 ä¸‹åˆ)â€©Hi Dai Zhang, allow me to try replying: UCP tag is still based on stream in underlying protocol. So it is possible that a partial transfer occurs. The need to specify the datatype and size is to ensure that a complete data element is presented when there is partial transfer.â€©I was looking into the same questions as well, this is my conclusion from reading the source. But it is better if Gil can confirmâ€©geofengå¯¹æ‰€æœ‰äººè¯´ï¼š (4:18 ä¸‹åˆ)Thanks Lih Wei, very good practice. In the mean time, I'm check with UCX R&D team, will get back to you once I get feedbackâ€©Dai Zhangå¯¹æ‰€æœ‰äººè¯´ï¼š (4:18 ä¸‹åˆ)â€©But I think the semantic of completion is all or nothing, even though the underlying method transfer the data in many pieces, we can only get completion notification when all pieces gathered.â€©Lih Weiå¯¹æ‰€æœ‰äººè¯´ï¼š (4:21 ä¸‹åˆ)â€©That is true for tag, maybe this only applies for the ucp_stream_* functions moreâ€©geofengå¯¹æ‰€æœ‰äººè¯´ï¼š (4:22 ä¸‹åˆ)â€©Good discussion!â€©Lih Weiå¯¹æ‰€æœ‰äººè¯´ï¼š (4:24 ä¸‹åˆ)â€©My other theory is that underlying buffer may be scattered if no contiguous buffer can be found, datatype is required to ensure that the splitting of buffer occur at data boundaryâ€©Dai Zhangå¯¹æ‰€æœ‰äººè¯´ï¼š (4:27 ä¸‹åˆ)â€©Good point. But it's a contiguous memory, the splitting and scattering needs an additional memory-copy. I think which the RDMA want to avoid.â€©Dai Zhangå¯¹æ‰€æœ‰äººè¯´ï¼š (4:28 ä¸‹åˆ)â€©But for the benefit of specifing size, I think the ucx interface chooses the right recv buffer size to avoid watsing memory. Is there some thing related to that?â€©Just in eager mode.â€©Qingchun Songå¯¹æ‰€æœ‰äººè¯´ï¼š (4:31 ä¸‹åˆ)â€©Hi, All, if you have any questions, please write in chat window.â€©Dai Zhangå¯¹æ‰€æœ‰äººè¯´ï¼š (4:32 ä¸‹åˆ)â€©Another another question, about the interface changes. In UCX v1.9, there is a new tag_send_nbx interface. It seems the datatype is put into the params argument, not the first-class argument yet. Is the interface of UCX not stable yet?â€©Dai Zhangå¯¹æ‰€æœ‰äººè¯´ï¼š (4:35 ä¸‹åˆ)â€©ucs_status_ptr_t ucp_stream_send_nbx(ucp_ep_h ep, const void *buffer, size_t count, const ucp_request_param_t *param)â€©Qingchun Songå¯¹æ‰€æœ‰äººè¯´ï¼š (4:35 ä¸‹åˆ)â€©Everyone can give the comments. this is the open discussion time.â€©Dai Zhangå¯¹æ‰€æœ‰äººè¯´ï¼š (4:35 ä¸‹åˆ)â€©The word may be improper. I means the datatype is not shown in function prototypeâ€©Qingchun Songå¯¹æ‰€æœ‰äººè¯´ï¼š (4:35 ä¸‹åˆ)â€©Welcome any comments.â€©Gil will answer all questions later today.â€©Dai tag,â€¨ucp_send_callback_t     cb â€¨)â€©Hereâ€™s the old interfaceâ€©Qingchun Songå¯¹æ‰€æœ‰äººè¯´ï¼š (4:39 ä¸‹åˆ)â€©we will set 1 hour Q&A Tina again at tomorrowâ€©we will set 1 hour Q&A time again Day06

èŠå¤©è®°å½•

geofengå¯¹æ‰€æœ‰äººè¯´ï¼š (9:05 ä¸Šåˆ)â€©Answers for the questions of yesterday:â€©geofengå¯¹æ‰€æœ‰äººè¯´ï¼š (9:05 ä¸Šåˆ)â€©1.    About datatypes and buffers. In general case datatype may describe non-contig data, for example it may represent matrix (set of buffers + padding data) where useful data is split by holes which should not be processed during send/receive operations. But in simple case, when used contig datatypes, it is just solid buffer, size may be calculated as count * size(datatype). Such semantics is reflecting MPI datatypes.â€©geofengå¯¹æ‰€æœ‰äººè¯´ï¼š (9:05 ä¸Šåˆ)â€©2.    Cross-polling workers and requests. Worker progress is polling only own requests which were created using this particular worker. You have to progress all workers which were used to create request, there is no way to workers cross-polling of requests. There is no limitation for cores to progress workers: worker is representation of â€œthread contextâ€, you may use one thread to post operation and another thread to progress it. If UCX is built with multithread mode and worker is created with multithreaded mode (see ucs_thread_mode_t, ucp_worker_params_t and ucp_worker_create) then UCX will serialize all operations for worker.â€©geofengå¯¹æ‰€æœ‰äººè¯´ï¼š (9:05 ä¸Šåˆ)â€©3.    NBX interface. In UCX 1.9 we added new set of API â€“ request based interfaces named NBX (non-block extended). For params which may be omitted (for example your program is operating by single char based buffers, no complex data and no callbacks are used to notify completions) user may pass empty ucp_request_param_t parameter and UCX excludes some overhead from processing of data which may improve performance of data transfer and application. This interface is stable and we are not going to change it in nearest future.â€©geofengå¯¹æ‰€æœ‰äººè¯´ï¼š (9:05 ä¸Šåˆ)â€©@Zai Zhangâ€©Dai Zhangå¯¹æ‰€æœ‰äººè¯´ï¼š (9:12 ä¸Šåˆ)â€©Gotit! Thank you!!â€©

entry.title: Hello World
entry.content:
Welcome to Hexo! This is your very first post. Check documentation for more info. If you get any problems when using Hexo, you can find the answer in troubleshooting or you can ask me on GitHub.

Quick Start

Create a new post

$ hexo new "My New Post"

More info: Writing

Run server

$ hexo server

More info: Server

Generate static files

$ hexo generate

More info: Generating

Deploy to remote sites

$ hexo deploy

More info: Deployment
